channel.title: How to maintain knowledge?
channel.description:
I finished school last June and because I am applying for uni in Australia, I have to wait till the end of February before I get back to studying.
I have already forgotten a lot of what I have learnt through A-level. I need ideas on how I can maintain the knowledge I have gained through A-level. I fear that when the time comes that I go to uni, I won't be as capable as I should be.
I've already given away most, if not all of my books. Ideas?
tl;dr
How can I not forget the stuff I studied in school?

item.title: How to maintain knowledge?
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

Phaze One:

Which uni have you applied for/which state?

All of them in victoria. Monash/RMIT/Victoria

item.title: How to maintain knowledge?
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

Lothy:

If you have 9 months off from now Radeon, and you actually enjoy doing maths on your own time, you could really get ahead of the curve by doing all of the videos on khanacademy.

Haha too bad I don’t enjoy doing maths in my own time. It’s just that these days the guilt of forgetting is overpowering me.

[quote=“la­wl, post:9, topic:371138”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=467217.msg3417004#msg3417004 date=1291170121]
If you have 9 months off from now Radeon, and you actually enjoy doing maths on your own time, you could really get ahead of the curve by doing all of the videos on khanacademy.
[/quote]
or look at course descriptions and study the topics listed, and get the books required for the courses you’re taking and read ahead[/quote]

Great suggestion. But I only find out which course I get accepted into on January 17th :S.

Read full topic

item.title: How to maintain knowledge?
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:10, topic:371138”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=467217.msg3417067#msg3417067 date=1291174839]

If you have 9 months off from now Radeon, and you actually enjoy doing maths on your own time, you could really get ahead of the curve by doing all of the videos on khanacademy.

or look at course descriptions and study the topics listed, and get the books required for the courses you’re taking and read ahead
[/quote]
That could be a mistake though. The textbook list could be updated due to new editions, etc. Or perhaps a new lecturer enters the fray and prefers one textbook over the previous textbook.
Whatever the case may be, the books can change and it can be a real pain.[/quote]
well it doesn’t matter, course content shouldn’t change often and if it does it will at most be a change in order of material learned or one section added/removed

in the engineering programs at my uni, book edition changes usually just end up being the addition of some random crap just so they can sell a new textbook.

Read full topic

item.title: How to maintain knowledge?
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:5, topic:371138”]It also helps to start studying quite some time before the tests. I tend to start studying a day or two before the tests, which gives decent results but most of it doesn’t stay in my memory longer then a week or two.

And thanks Lothy, exactly what I needed to refresh my Maths.[/quote]

That is where I went wrong too.

Due to me changing hemispheres(lol) for uni, I am in the midst of a 9 month summer holiday which has been detrimental to the knowledge I have acquired at school.

Read full topic

item.description:

It also helps to start studying quite some time before the tests. I tend to start studying a day or two before the tests, which gives decent results but most of it doesn’t stay in my memory longer then a week or two.

And thanks Lothy, exactly what I needed to refresh my Maths.

item.title: How to maintain knowledge?
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

http://www.khanacademy.org/ is ideal for my situation. What I needed is something to re-simulate the lessons I’ve had in class.

Some of it is obviously trapped in my brain somewhere, but I feel that during school I did not exert enough effort to ensure what I learnt would stick to my head. A lot of the things I would just memorize for the moment and never think about them ever again.

Read full topic

item.title: How to maintain knowledge?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Maybe it feels like you’ve forgotten it, but it’s still there. All you need is to refresh your memory via summary’s (like Schaum’s) and you’ll be fine. There’s no way you can recite everything you’ve learnt after a few months, without working with it on a weekly basis.

Read full topic

item.title: How to maintain knowledge?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Which subjects? In my opinion, I think the best learning is done by using at least two methods (ie, reading and hearing/listening), with content repeated over x days.

So say I was learning a foreign language, and working on vocabulary building.
Firstly, I’d pick 20 - 30 words per day. Secondly, I’d write them out, reading as I go. Thirdly, I’d consider recording myself saying the word followed by the meaning. And then I’d listen to that recording.
Basically, memory retention is enhanced by activating more areas of the brain AND repeating over consecutive days. You’re basically creating as many pathways as you can to the memory within your brain, using as many methods as possible.

If it’s a maths based subject (or even chemistry, among other sciences) then use http://www.khanacademy.org/.

Read full topic
